User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0
Build ID: 20110615151330

Steps to reproduce:

I've tested an example taken from this page:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/event.pageX
It gets correct result for 100% zoom (Ctrl 0)
When the page is zoomed in/out (Ctrl +/-) the event.PageX returns unexpected results. Surprisingly, event.PageY seems to be Ok.


Actual results:

When the top left corner of the blue rectangle with obtained values is clicked, it displays pageX=412 (-4x), 309 (-3x), 256 (-2x), 230 (-1x), 204 (0x), 189 (+1x), 170 (+2x)  where number in () means how many times the original has been zoomed out (-) or in (+). Exact zoom is not visible anywhere!


Expected results:

I would expect to get the value of 204 px at every zoom.

comments.text:
> Which blue rectangle? 
That rectangle with obtained values, bottom left.

I originally found this problem in my SVG script that calculates the angle to the center of my full-screen SVG image. It works fine in MSIE9 (independently on the zoom), but it is broken in FF. Finally I found a difference in the returned pageX value and following story you already know.

> layout of the page changes when the page is zoomed
Seems to be connected to the absolute/relative positioning. The Y coord is fixed so it returns almost the same value all the time while X is defined as 20% so the final value is somehow updated when zoom is changed.

If this behaviour is correct, then this issue can be resolved as invalid. Anyway, I have to investigate more reliable way for getting the mouse position.

I originally found this problem in my SVG script that calculates the angle to the center of my full-screen SVG image. It works fine in MSIE9 (independently on the zoom), but it is broken in FF. Finally I found a difference in the returned pageX value and following story you already know.

> layout of the page changes when the page is zoomed
Seems to be connected to the absolute/relative positioning. The Y coord is fixed so it returns almost the same value all the time while X is defined as 20% so the final value is somehow updated when zoom is changed.

If this behaviour is correct, then this issue can be resolved as invalid. Anyway, I have to investigate more reliable way for getting the mouse position.

> while X is defined as 20% so the final value is somehow updated when zoom is
> changed.

Right.  Zoom changes the size of a CSS px, so changes the width of the browser window measured in CSS px, and 20% of that width will be a different number as a result.  That part of the behavior is correct, I believe.
